## Small‑Town Fluoridation in Action  
Below is a **walk‑through of a “day‑in‑the‑life”** for a water‑utility that serves a community of about **5,000 people** (≈ 2 MGD – 2 million gallons per day). The plant operates 24 h a day, 7 days a week, with a staff of three operators (one on‑site, two on‑call).  

> **Key point:**  Even a very small system follows the same basic steps that a large city does—only the hardware is scaled down and many tasks are combined.

---

### 1.  Set‑up (once every 6‑12 months)

| Activity | Who does it | What is recorded |
|----------|------------|------------------|
| **Calibration of the dosing pump** | Lead operator (or a contracted engineer) | Pump flow‑rate (L h⁻¹) at the set‑point, verified with a calibrated **gravimetric test** (weigh water before/after a known pump run). |
| **Verification of fluoride source concentration** | Supplier provides a Certificate of Analysis (CoA). The utility runs a **lab check** on a sample to confirm the % fluoride (e.g., 12 % F‑ in 30 % H₂SiF₆). | Recorded in the “Source‑Verification Log”. |
| **Update of target concentration** | Decision made by the municipal health board, usually 0.7 mg F/L (U.S. CDC) or the locally‑adopted value. | Documented in the “Fluoridation Policy”. |

---

### 2.  Daily Operations – Morning Shift (07:00 – 15:00)

| Time | Task | Equipment / Method | Typical Data (example) |
|------|------|--------------------|------------------------|
| 07:00 | **Check control‑room console** – verify that the **online fluorometer** is online, the pump status light is green, and the data‑logger is recording. | Fluorometer (ion‑selective electrode) with automatic temperature compensation; SCADA/PLC screen. | “Fluorometer OK – 0.68 mg/L”. |
| 07:15 | **Review yesterday’s log** for any alarms (high/low fluoride, pump fault). | Paper/ electronic log (often a simple spreadsheet). | No alarms yesterday. |
| 08:00 | **Take a “grab sample”** from the finished‑water line (post‑disinfection, pre‑distribution) for **independent lab verification** (sent to the county health lab). | Sterile 250 mL HDPE bottle, labeled with date/time, flow‑meter reading. | Sample sent; expected result 0.68 ± 0.05 mg/L. |
| 09:30 | **Inspect the dosing pump** – visual check of diaphragm, check for leaks, listen for abnormal noise. | Pump manual, flashlight. | Pump looks clean; no leaks. |
| 11:00 | **Mid‑day fluorometer reading** – note the value on the console and write it to the daily log. | Console read‑out. | 0.70 mg/L (still within ± 0.1 mg/L of target). |
| 12:30 | **Adjust pump set‑point (if needed)** – if the reading drifts > 0.05 mg/L from target, the operator changes the pump’s **set‑point percentage** (e.g., from 2.8 % to 2.9 %). | Pump controller knob or SCADA “set‑point” entry. | No change needed today. |
